phrasal verbs.meaning: without a home to live in

phrasal verbs.meaning: enjoying nightlife in a city

idioms.meaning: to stay serious and not laugh

topic vocab.meaning: to legally force someone to leave their house; đuổi khỏi
topic vocab.example: The letter says they’re going to evict us next week.

topic vocab.meaning: a high-rise building is very tall with many floors or levels; cao tầng
topic vocab.example: She lives in a high-rise in the city centre.

topic vocab.meaning: buildings for people to live in; nhà ở
topic vocab.example: The government has announced more housing for the poor.

topic vocab.meaning: the basic systems and services that a country or organization uses; cơ sở hạ tầng
topic vocab.example: During the war, a lot of the infrastructure of the country was destroyed.

topic vocab.meaning: the central part of a large city where there is a lot of poverty and social problems; nội đô, khu ổ chuột
topic vocab.example: There are some very interesting music coming out of the inner city these days.

topic vocab.meaning: to live in or use a space or building; chiếm giữ, cư trú
topic vocab.example: Patients with minor illnesses are occupying beds that are needed for more serious cases.

topic vocab.meaning: firm and difficult to bend; cứng
topic vocab.example: Take a stiff piece of card and cut a hole in it.

topic vocab.meaning: a hole in a piece of paper, cloth, etc where it has been torn; vết rách
topic vocab.example: There’s a big tear in my jeans.

topic vocab.meaning: a high-rise building is very tall with many floors or levels; cao tầng
topic vocab.example: She lives in a high-rise in the city centre.

topic vocab.meaning: looking sad, as if you expect something bad to happen; rầu rĩ
topic vocab.example: You look a bit glum. Has something happened?

topic vocab.meaning: an ugly expression made by twisting your face, often because you are in pain or do not like something; biểu hiện nhăn nhó
topic vocab.example: His tortured grimace showed he was in pain.

topic vocab.meaning: to make an ugly expression by twisting your face, for example because you are in pain or do not like something; nhăn mặt
topic vocab.example: She grimaced as the needle went in.

topic vocab.meaning: a big smile that shows your teeth; nụ cười tươi
topic vocab.example: Mike said nothing, but just sat there with a big grin.

topic vocab.meaning: to smile showing your teeth; cười tươi
topic vocab.example: Ruth grinned at him as she waved goodbye.

topic vocab.meaning: to take action to deal with a difficult situation; xử lý
topic vocab.example: The government was criticised for how it handled the crisis.

topic vocab.meaning: annoyed because something is not happening as quickly as you want or in the way you want; thiếu kiên nhẫn
topic vocab.example: ‘Come on!’ said Maggie, becoming impatient.

topic vocab.meaning: a situation in which something does not change for a long time; sự trì trệ
topic vocab.example: There’s so much inertia in the system.

topic vocab.meaning: traditionally accepted behaviour that shows politeness; tác phong
topic vocab.example: Children learn manners from their parents.

topic vocab.meaning: an action or movement that you need care or skill to do; động tác khéo léo
topic vocab.example: Expert driving manoeuvres are key when reversing the truck.

topic vocab.meaning: to move someone or something in a situation that needs care or skill; điều khiển khéo léo
topic vocab.example: Katherine’s good at manoeuvring her car through narrow gaps.

topic vocab.meaning: a long low sound you make because of pain, sadness or pleasure; tiếng rên
topic vocab.example: He let out a moan of anguish.

topic vocab.meaning: to complain about something in an annoying way; than vãn
topic vocab.example: Ben was moaning about his job again.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone or something look stupid by laughing at them; chế giễu
topic vocab.example: Are you trying to mock me?

topic vocab.meaning: failure to give someone or something the care or attention they need; sự bỏ bê
topic vocab.example: There is an important need to protect children from abuse and neglect.

topic vocab.meaning: to fail to look after someone when you should do so; bỏ bê
topic vocab.example: What should we do about parents who neglect their children?

topic vocab.meaning: to fail to do something you should do; sao nhãng
topic vocab.example: He couldn’t neglect his duties as an officer.

topic vocab.meaning: a quick look at something; cái nhìn trộm
topic vocab.example: I’ll just take a peep inside.

topic vocab.meaning: to look at something quickly and secretly; nhìn trộm
topic vocab.example: She tried to peep through the door into the garden.

topic vocab.meaning: to look very carefully, especially because something is difficult to see; nhìn săm soi
topic vocab.example: She was peering at the screen trying to read the small print.

topic vocab.meaning: a populated area has people living there; đông dân
topic vocab.example: Luckily, the fire didn’t spread to populated areas.

topic vocab.meaning: the shapes made by buildings or mountains against the sky; hình dáng in lên nền trời
topic vocab.example: I love the London skyline.

topic vocab.meaning: a very tall building containing offices or flats; tòa nhà chọc trời
topic vocab.example: Skyscrapers started to appear in the 1930s.

topic vocab.meaning: something large such as a building or bridge built from different parts; cấu trúc
topic vocab.example: The large structure outside town is going to be the new stadium.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to an area on the edge of a city; ngoại ô
topic vocab.example: Many people would love to live in suburban areas but can’t afford it.

topic vocab.meaning: all things present in a place that form the experience of being there; môi trường xung quanh
topic vocab.example: I wish I lived in more pleasant surroundings.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to towns and cities; thành thị
topic vocab.example: There needs to be more investment in urban areas.

topic vocab.meaning: to accept or admit that something exists or is true; công nhận, thừa nhận
topic vocab.example: He never acknowledges his mistakes.

topic vocab.meaning: to thank someone for something they have done; bày tỏ lòng biết ơn
topic vocab.example: We gratefully acknowledge the contributions of everyone who helped us.

topic vocab.meaning: to show you have seen someone, for example by smiling; tỏ ra đã nhận ra
topic vocab.example: They barely acknowledge each other in public.

topic vocab.meaning: to spend a long time worrying or being upset about something; chịu lo lắng, khổ sở
topic vocab.example: For years I agonised over whether I could have helped my daughter.

topic vocab.meaning: a feeling of having no interest or enthusiasm; sự lãnh đạm
topic vocab.example: Few people voted in the election, presumably just because of apathy.

topic vocab.meaning: to try to prevent something from happening; ngăn ngừa
topic vocab.example: Try to avoid confrontation.

topic vocab.meaning: to try not to go near someone or something; tránh xa
topic vocab.example: We went early to avoid the crowds.

topic vocab.meaning: to choose not to do something to achieve a better result; nên tránh
topic vocab.example: When taking this medication it is advisable to avoid alcohol.

topic vocab.meaning: the way that someone behaves; hành vi
topic vocab.example: Anna was sick of her brother’s behaviour.

topic vocab.meaning: a quiet laugh; nụ cười thầm
topic vocab.example: There were a couple of chuckles from one member of the audience.

topic vocab.meaning: to laugh quietly; cười thầm
topic vocab.example: As she read her book, she chuckled softly.

topic vocab.meaning: a physically relaxed state, without any pain or unpleasant feelings; sự an nhiên
topic vocab.example: The airline is keen to improve passenger comfort.

topic vocab.meaning: a feeling of being less sad or worried about something than before; sự an ủi
topic vocab.example: My mother was always there to offer comfort.

topic vocab.meaning: a pleasant way of life in which you have everything you need; sung túc
topic vocab.example: Now he can live in comfort for the rest of his life.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone feel less sad, worried or disappointed; an ủi
topic vocab.example: He went upstairs to comfort the baby.

topic vocab.meaning: the way someone behaves in relation to particular rules; cách đạo đức
topic vocab.example: Two players were sent off for violent conduct.

topic vocab.meaning: to do something in an organised way; thực hiện
topic vocab.example: The agreement doesn’t allow you to conduct business from your home.

topic vocab.meaning: a result or effect of something; hậu quả
topic vocab.example: She said exactly what she felt, without fear of the consequences.

topic vocab.meaning: the happiness you feel when you have everything you want; sự mãn nguyện
topic vocab.example: He has found contentment and satisfaction in his work.

topic vocab.meaning: angry; bực mình, cáu
topic vocab.example: The neighbours got cross every time we put our music on.

topic vocab.meaning: impressive behaviour of someone who controls their emotions; phẩm giá
topic vocab.example: She faced all her problems with dignity.

topic vocab.meaning: a very strong feeling of not liking something; sự ghê tởm
topic vocab.example: The idea of eating meat fills me with disgust.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone angry and upset; làm ghê tởm
topic vocab.example: Your whole attitude disgusts me.

topic vocab.meaning: disappointed because something is not as good as you believed; vỡ mộng
topic vocab.example: Voters are very disillusioned with the democratic process.

topic vocab.meaning: annoyed or bored with something you have accepted for too long; chán ghét
topic vocab.example: I’m fed up with this job.

topic vocab.meaning: a high laugh, especially a nervous or silly one; cười khúc khích
topic vocab.example: The sound of giggles came from the girls’ room.

topic vocab.meaning: to laugh in a nervous or silly way; cười khúc khích
topic vocab.example: The children whispered and giggled all the way through the film.

topic vocab.meaning: a quick look at someone or something; cái liếc mắt
topic vocab.example: She had a quick glance at the newspaper as she gulped down her coffee.

topic vocab.meaning: to look somewhere quickly then look away; liếc
topic vocab.example: He glanced over his shoulder nervously.

topic vocab.meaning: an occasion when you see someone or something for a moment; cái nhìn thoáng qua
topic vocab.example: The crowd were anxious for a glimpse of the President.

topic vocab.meaning: to see someone or something for a moment or not completely; nhìn thoáng qua
topic vocab.example: He glimpsed a short white-haired figure heading for the back gate.

topic vocab.meaning: to show you are happy and proud at someone else’s failure; hách dịch
topic vocab.example: He was there to gloat over their defeat.

topic vocab.meaning: to stop something from happening or stop someone from doing something; cản, ngăn
topic vocab.example: Regular cleaning may help prevent infection.

topic vocab.meaning: to feel very happy about something; vui mừng
topic vocab.example: Montenegro seemed to rejoice in the humiliation of others.

topic vocab.meaning: to experience anger or bitterness because you think you have been treated unfairly; bực tức
topic vocab.example: The family resented all the attention their pets were getting.

topic vocab.meaning: to formally decide; kiên quyết
topic vocab.example: We’re resolved to win the contract.

topic vocab.meaning: an unpleasant way of smiling because something bad has happened to someone else; nụ cười nhếch mép
topic vocab.example: Wipe that smirk off your face!

topic vocab.meaning: to smile in an unpleasant way because something bad has happened to someone else; cười nhếch mép
topic vocab.example: I know you’ve won, but there’s no need to smirk.

topic vocab.meaning: to suddenly lose control and speak or act angrily; nổi cáu
topic vocab.example: ‘What do you want now?’ he snapped angrily.

topic vocab.meaning: to speak to someone in a sudden angry way; quát tháo
topic vocab.example: The governor’s tactics involved snapping at those who were too liberal.

topic vocab.meaning: a particular method or plan for achieving something; chiến thuật
topic vocab.example: The governor’s tactics involved a mix of discipline and support.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong feeling of fear; sự kinh hoàng
topic vocab.example: Thousands of residents fled in terror yesterday as the volcano erupted.

topic vocab.meaning: violence used for making people very frightened in order to achieve political aims; sự khủng bố
topic vocab.example: This is a deliberate campaign of terror.

topic vocab.meaning: to give someone a drug or medical treatment; phát thuốc
topic vocab.example: The drugs are administered intravenously.

topic vocab.meaning: to take someone into hospital for medical treatment; tiếp nhận vào viện
topic vocab.example: After collapsing, she was rushed to hospital, where she was admitted.

topic vocab.meaning: great pain; cơn đau đớn
topic vocab.example: William fell to the ground, writhing in agony.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong and unpleasant feeling, especially great worry or sadness; sự đau khổ
topic vocab.example: Waiting for the results was agony.

topic vocab.meaning: a substance that prevents a poison from having bad effects; thuốc giải độc
topic vocab.example: It’s a snake bite. Quick — get the antidote!

topic vocab.meaning: a senior doctor in a hospital who is an expert in a particular medical subject; bác sĩ tham vấn
topic vocab.example: She’s a consultant cardiologist.

grammar.meaning: The passive is used when the doer is unknown, obvious, unimportant, or to create a formal tone. (Câu bị động dùng khi không rõ, không quan trọng hoặc không muốn nhắc tới chủ thể hành động)
grammar.example: The car was stolen at approximately 1.30 am. / The XL500 was designed with young families in mind. / This type of submarine was developed during WWII. / We were surprised by the number of people trying to leave the city. / All passengers are required to present their ticket.

grammar.meaning: Used to express general beliefs, expectations, or assumptions. Often starts with 'It is thought...', 'Tourism is expected to...', etc. (Dùng bị động vô danh để nói về suy nghĩ/quan điểm chung)
grammar.example: Tourism is expected to become a major part of the country’s economy. / It is thought that the new railway will provide employment opportunities. / There are reported to have been a record number of accidents.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Direct and indirect object
grammar.meaning: Some verbs allow two objects (person + thing). In passive, either object can become subject. (Dùng bị động với câu có 2 tân ngữ — trực tiếp và gián tiếp)
grammar.example: Michael gave the plane tickets to Jill. / Jill was given the plane tickets (by Michael). / The plane tickets were given to Jill (by Michael). / How to drive the train was explained to me.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Avoiding the passive
grammar.meaning: Used when passive is awkward or not natural in continuous/perfect tenses. We use prepositional phrases instead. (Tránh dùng bị động bằng cách dùng cụm giới từ phù hợp hơn)
grammar.example: Preparations for the flight will be in progress as the President arrives. / At the end of this year, I will have been in training as a pilot for four years. / Vintage cars have been on display in the town centre. / The problem had been under consideration. / The railway station has been under construction for two years now.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get/have something done
grammar.meaning: Used when someone arranges for someone else to do something for them. (Cấu trúc nhờ ai đó làm gì cho mình)
grammar.example: Did you finally get your bike fixed? / I heard that Susie had her motorbike stolen. / I’d like those cars washed by this evening. / We’ll set off as soon as I’ve got the car fixed.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get sb to do / have sb do
grammar.meaning: Used to say someone persuades or arranges for someone else to do something. (Dùng khi khiến ai đó làm việc gì)
grammar.example: Did you get Alex to drive you all the way to London? / I had my assistant book the tickets.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get/have sb doing
grammar.meaning: Used to say someone starts someone else doing something. (Dùng khi khiến ai đó bắt đầu làm gì đó)
grammar.example: Don’t worry. We’ll soon have your car running like new. / That film got me thinking about my childhood.

grammar.meaning: The passive is used when the doer is unknown, obvious, unimportant, or to create a formal tone. (Câu bị động dùng khi không rõ, không quan trọng hoặc không muốn nhắc tới chủ thể hành động)
grammar.example: The car was stolen at approximately 1.30 am. / The XL500 was designed with young families in mind. / This type of submarine was developed during WWII. / We were surprised by the number of people trying to leave the city. / All passengers are required to present their ticket.

grammar.example: Tourism is expected to become a major part of the country’s economy. / It is thought that the new railway will provide employment opportunities. / There are reported to have been a record number of accidents.

grammar.example: Michael gave the plane tickets to Jill. / Jill was given the plane tickets (by Michael). / The plane tickets were given to Jill (by Michael). / How to drive the train was explained to me.
